title: Long time User - this is the best
content: Iâ€™ve been using BusyCal since it came out - absolutely love this app.  Especially the ability to look at multiple weeks at a time!

title: Not Easy to Navigate
content: I will stick with the calendar I am using.  I need simplicity. I will be deleting this app.

title: Love It
content: This app is fantastic. My favorite feature is that it hides duplicate appointments (I have multiple calendars I manage and sometimes need things in multiple places but hated seeing the dups on my calendars)

title: Widget went crazy
content: For some reason the widget refocused and the border gets cut off. Half the dates on the left and right side are cut off. Also would be nice if you can scroll in the widget to next/prev months

title: Difficult to Navigate
content: App is difficult to navigate and get other calendars to sync.  Not intuitive at all.  Multiple areas have to be clicked before a calendar will link-up.  I actually had to uninstall and reinstall one of the external calendars to get it to work.

title: Great software, great business
content: BusyCal does a lot of small things right.  As a frequent traveler that lives outside the USA, I value especially the robust support for time zones.  BusyCal goes way beyond MacOS Calendars, without trying to also do a bunch of unrelated things like social networking or advertising other products. Iâ€™ve been using BC for so long I take its advanced features for granted.  Another reason I love this product is the speedy and friendly support they give and quick response.  They clearly want to listen to their customers in order to improve and repair their product.  I just wanted to take a second and give them the 5 stars they deserve from a satisfied customer.

title: Fantastic calendar, fantastic company
content: This is the calendar app that all calendar apps claim to be but never are. It handles everything perfectly, with rarely ever a hiccup, has every feature you need, and their support is as good as anyone could reasonably ask for.

title: Busy Mom + Business Owner
content: Iâ€™ve been a BusyCal user for 5+ years. I canâ€™t live without it. Nothing is better for organizing multiple calendars and reminder lists. From my laptop to my iPad to my phone itâ€™s always there. When my son started college he asked me how I organize all I do and I showed him BusyCal, he uses it now too!

title: Time does not happen in months
content: Iâ€™ve been a fan of BusyCal for years (decades, actually!  Started in 2005).  I like that I can have color coded separate categories (family, work, social, medical, volunteer, subscriptions, homemaintenance, etc) and also add google calendars.  Many calendars do this.  My favorite feature is that you can set how many weeks to see at a time (in month view) AND the borders between months do not have special status.  I usually show six weeks at a time starting with todayâ€™s week.  I can scroll forward (or back) by week, not just by month.  Makes planning so much easier what I can frame the events I am focusing on, even if the donâ€™t all occur in the same calendar month.  Support is great too!

title: Functions exactly as I wanted
content: For the price, this is among the best options for calendar apps I have found, especially since Fantastical raised their prices to the moon. This app has a similar 'natural language' input style and visual appeal to Fantastical but at a much lower rate. The devs are still actively putting out updates regularly which is deeply appreciated. I really like the heat map that shows the corresponding event density, making it easier to plan my days. I do wish there are more appearance/theme options to customize the look.

title: Exactly what I needed
content: BusyCal makes it a snap to manage all of my calendars, reminders, and online meeting tools. Iâ€™ve tried many other apps and BusyCal is by far the most intuitive and easy to use. Cannot recommend it highly enough!

title: Glitch when entering a new item in Calendar
content: Recently I can only type a few letters in a new entry and then the cursor jumps elsewhere on my screen and the new entry terminates. This has been happening for the past 3-4 weeks. Very annoying...

title: Can not live without it
content: Puts shame on apple ical this cal does it ALL. Works for an ADHD mind, keeps me organized & on task & on time. I will NEVER go back. You need this cal.

title: Best Calendar and Task Manager I have ever used!
content: I have tried many calendar and task management apps over the years and nobody does it as well as BusyCal. It is simply the best Calendar and Task Management app that I have to manage my time and to keep track of my tasks. In my case, it works seamlessly with my multiple Google accounts and also my iCloud account. I highly recommend this app to anyone who is looking to get their time and tasks organized. Kudoâ€™s to the development team!

title: Todo Durations! ðŸ¤¯
content:
This is by far the best Calendar and Todo List App! Way better than fantastical! Love the new Task Durations! This is really becoming a super powerful all in one calendar app! 

Feature Request: Please add support for nested tasks/Subtasks. Thats the only thing thatâ€™s left for me now. I still need to return to Todoist or Reminders to see subtasks.

title: holidays?
content: still canâ€™t add holidays

title: Not Working
content: Where do I select calender in calender's list??

title: Great replacement for native Apple Calendar
content: Only reason for dinging a star is the cost.  Comparable to the iOS version itâ€™s a bit steep, at least for me as I do 90+% of my calendaring on my phone.  That said the free desktop version is a fantastic option for me and it pairs well with the iOS version now that there is cross platform syncing.  Iâ€™ve used a lot of other calendars over the years and I can say that BusyCal is hands down the best in class, created by developers who are actively working to improve the app regularly.

title: Malware that is very difficult to uninstall
content: Many people are talking online about the shady ways this app leaches onto the system and hides, even after you remove it from the application folder. Donâ€™t trust a company like this, even if itâ€™s popular.

title: Decent Feature
content: The client has a fairly good feature set. My biggest issue is a farily frequent "stubbornness" to sync with iCloud.

title: This app is a joy to use
content: It integrates all of the different scheudles I have, and does the one thing that I need any scheduling software to do, it allows me to tag different events as Rocks, Pebbles, Sand, and Water. This may not make sense to you, but color coordinating my schedule this way makes my life so much easier.

title: apple should learn
content: this is sooo much better than apple's calendar app.  Very sophisticated!!!

title: Great app - great support!
content: I've been using BusyCal for about three months now.  Very happy with both the app and the developers support.  My one wish is that it would integrate with Edison mail (my favorite), but all in all, very happy with zoom integration and other features.

title: 5  stars for the Busy-Guys at Busy-Mac (BusyCal, BusyContacts, Busy iOS)
content: Our all-Mac family of 2 parents, 4 teenage-young adult kids have used the Busy Mac products across all our Mac devinces including phones, laptops, desktops, tablets since almost the beginning of BusyMac in 2007.  Worth every penny and the BusyGuys respond promptly when we have any issues.  We only give them 5 stars because the App Store doesn't have any higher ratings.

title: Good App.
content: Figured it out with a little help from my (IT) friends. Love the app. I donâ€™t use it on Sundays. Comfy to use. Recommend. Responsive Deva, too. So easy.

title: Can't get it to open on my laptop or phone
content: but works on desktop for years. Yes, I made a special key, read online ideas, and fooled around for hours.

title: Didn't work for me
content: I was looking for an app that would seem the recombine both my iCloud calendar and reminders. While I was able to get the iCloud calendars working with a little bit of hassle, I learned from the developers website that I was not allowed to sync my iCloud reminders to apples decision to no longer support CalDav. I'm a bit confused by this. If the developers are not able to integrate peoples' iCloud reminders into BusyCal, why is it that apps such as Fantastical can easily integrate iCloud Reminders?

title: "In App Purchase" required to work
content:
I thought that "In App Purchase" meant that I would at least be able to try the product before comitting. Not true. As soon as I added a calendar, my only choices were to commit to paying or quit.

Sure, they said there was a "Free Trial", but that "Free Trial" meant that I had to sign up and then opt out. It did not mean "Free Trial, and THEN opt-in".

In other words, I felt tricked into installing it before being told I had to commit to paying before I could use it.

title: Sync with apple
content: to difficult to sync to apple calendar

title: Close to greatness, needs account sync
content: Needs account sync across devices. I cannot be bothered to add invidual accoutns to every single device that I purchased busycal on. Need a unified sign on that syncs sign-on to all accounts across devices.

title: Not free
content: Don't download the app expecting it to be free. The second you open it you get the option to pay a bunch of money or quit the app.

title: Feature Rich, Works Well, Responsive Customer Support
content: Iâ€™ve been using BusyCal for years and found it to be the best after trying and researching numerous competitors.

title: Account
content: This app would be better if I could have access to the calendar accross mutliple devices. Other than that, a good app.

title: Tiá»‡n lá»£i
content: Tá»« khi chuyá»ƒn qua Mac OS thÃ¬  BusiCal lÃ  cá»©u cÃ¡nh cho mÃ¬nh trong viá»‡c quáº£n lÃ½ cÃ´ng viá»‡c hiá»‡u quáº£.

title: Seems like a great app
content: This app seems like it would be a nice app, but because of the stupid subscription I'm not trying it.

title: I hate apps asking for a review
content: I opened it and it asked me almost right after. I hate when apps do that. I haven't been able to use it yet. i wouldn't know how it is. 1 star for it wanting a review before I could really use it.

title: How the mighty has fallen
content: This used to be hands down the best calendar app and now it's a pain in the you know what.

title: Subscription Based
content: There's no free option.

title: great app IF you can figure out hoiw to sync!
content: cannot sync my tasks from Apple Reminders to busy cal tasks; yes i know about app specif password tho still not easy LOTS of nuances... ans no one to CALL. If it worked as I had used x years would be great tho "the tech is supposed to make life easier" mindset is certainly not falling into place for me. unfortunately think I will need cancel trail and consolidate my task just on reminders tho such does not allow me to see in ONE field as busy cal did tho now just a dream.

title: Excellent!
content: I love Busycal. Been using it for years. The only minor issue I have, which is I believe is related to Apple itself, is that task syncing is a little buggy at times. Busycal blows other calendars and task systems away! And I've tried a lot of other applications.

title: dates are incorrect
content: This program used to work fine for me, but over the last week, when I try to input starting and ending dates for an event, it changes them to incorrect ones. I have submitted a help request, but have not received a reply.

title: It's confusing to use
content: It's confusing to use and add tasks to my calander as well as delete them. I do like that it sets reminders on my phone as well. I mainly use this on my laptop.

title: Nightmare to uninstal
content: Took me forever to dig through my system files to find whatever kept re-installing the menu bar. I moved busyCal to the trash and even after that it would just re-instal the menu bar whenever I deleted the file. Took forever.

title: Essental to manage & organize happenings
content:
Started out with BusyMac back in my Stone Age to the universal app that it is now. It uses both Caqlendar and Reminders as underlying data stores,doing away the need to pay for other applications. 

I switched to Fantistica, for awhile when it first came out support for the Apple Watch; BusyCal has caight up, though. My severely technophobic other half is now also using BusyCal, as is my daughter in her executive-level job, along with friends to whom I recommended it to.

Glowing praise aside, there's isn't much of a learing curve to BusyCql. It works right out of the proverbiael box and is mosly self-explanatory. Take a look at the settings and, In time, you'll want to tweak it to your liking: connect with other calendars and manage tasks, for example. You don't even need to open Calendar and Reminders, perhaps just for the comfort of verifying data in either.

BusyCal jas replaced Fantastical and OmniFocus, simplifying my life tremendously.

title: DO believe the "hype", this App fixed my calendar chaos
content: iCal (as it was), Google Calendars x3, kids' calendars, etc--I couldn't find a way to keep things simple, but I had read reviews (reddit, elsewhere) of people recommending BusyCal for MacOS and iOS. I'm on the bandwagon now. It has helped me organize, streamline, simplify my calendars--centralizing things and being able to spend less time reorganizing things. I think there are a few minor wishes (can't send emails without MacOS "Mail" opening despite this not being my OS default app which is Gmail on Chrome, missing native Google Workspace features like seeing Google Calendar resources or invitees schedules, more granular control of tasks prioritization) but these don't stop me from giving this a 5 over a 4 (4.5 would've been my choice if it was possible). I installed this on my phone and feel the same. I still might use Google for some situations (like above) but I usually start from BusyCal and take over elsewhere for anything that needs native features. Hopefully, the devs behind this will find wasy to tap in to those features or maybe make their own solution. I'm a fan and think if you are struggling with multiple calendars, this will be your solution.

title: customizable and great to use
content: love the customizable options

title: Not sure how this is deemed user friendly.
content:
This app is not user friendly unless you have a programming background. The help section isn't helpful at all, and when you try to contact someone, you're basically yelling into the void. 
Can't color coordinate, can't get the app to work on my laptop (even after purchasing the app). It's a waste of time and of $10. Annoyed.

title: Do not download
content: As soon as I opened it, it only gave me the option of a free trial and then paid versions. I don't want all the bells and whistles. I just needed something for my classroom.

title: WORST APP
content: like you need to pay to use a calendar..

title: Not good for people that depend in color coding
content:
Hello, It's a great app, and I really like the one-payment option. However, I can only seem to be able to change colors for individual events on the Mac version and these event colors do not sync with the iOS version. 

I have a disability and rely on color coding some calendar events to navigage my week. 

Moving meeting invites to a calendar with a different color is not a solution, since it resends the meeting invite to attendees and inconveniences them. 

Please update the app so the individual event colors we pick for Mac events syncs with the iOS events. It's what the app needs to go from good to great. Thank You.

title: nagware
content: popup makes app unusable

title: I knew I was immediately going to love this app!
content: Yeah so, spent a lot of time looking for the "right" calendar app. I knew IMMEDIATELY that this one was going to be a winner. The layout, the feel, the integrations with all calendar types (especially Google), the TASK-CAL view is everthing, yeah it's def the best. LOVING IT.

title: Subscription
content: I have been using busycal on my phone for almost a year now and have experienced little to no issues. I just got a new macbook and downloaded busycal right away, but now it wont allow me to use the app until i pay for another subscription. My phone however is still working perfectly fine. How do i fix this?

title: Awesome
content: I've gone through way too many calendar/scheduling apps (Fantastical, Motion, Outlook, regular old Google Calendar, etc.), and this is the first one I've found that works well for a freelancer whose schedule is "flexible". Somehow, no other calendar seems to get these two things right that this app gets: 1. Multi-select and drag of events (for when you need to scoot "your whole day" forward by 1 hour due to some unforeseen event). 2. A truly arbitrary number of days in the "time block" view. You could do a whole month if you want (and I have on a 6k screen at times).

title: Fun to use
content: I'm starting a planner and this is so fun to use. It is convenient and cute too

title: Repeats main defect of Calendar
content:
I got this application hoping to avoid the defect in calendar -- putting days of the week names on the left edge of a column, right next to the content for activities on the following day. Unfortunately, there appears to be no way to adjust where it puts columns names.
I don't want it, but I can get rid of it.

title: BusyCal & 2Do Integration
content:
I really do love BusyCal but the Tasks module needs upgraded from a task list to a Task Manager.
I understand my favorite task manager 2Do and BusyCal is owned by same person.
I would love to have BusyCal & 2Do be integrated together.
I live in my calendar but need a stronger tasks features than what BusyCal offers.
I would really like to see that marrige between BusyCal & 2Do.

title: Abel
content: Jacinto

title: Does not work with Teams
content:
Ok calendar but not usable with Microsoft Teams which is a requirement at work.

So I have to cross reference calendars all the time.

title: busycal
content: best calendar app even better features thank mac calendar and still allows ical input buy it nice!

title: Best calendar out there
content: I've tried them all, and this is the best one. Intuitive, colorful, simple, it is the only calendar I use. My life can get complicated and I don't need a calendar to make things more complicated. I like the design and the simplicity of it. My only wish is that it had the ability to make other calendar groups, but then again I like having things clean and simple to avoid visual stress! I love that I can make notes on almost all entries, because that's how I work. I've been using this for years, they have made me a happy customer!

title: NOT FREE
content: THIS APP IS NOT FREE TO EVEN USE AND TRICKS YOU BY NOT INCLUDING THE PRICE UPON DOWNLOADING!

title: BusyCal
content: Very Satisfied with BusyCal and its very easy to use and satisfied with my daily use

title: Delivers Consistently
content:
In 25 years, this is my third review. 

I am always trying new apps, but for several years now, calendar apps aren't part of that. 

A great program that delivers like a Swiss watch.

title: Feeling unhappy with this app
content: I used to love this app (as a google cal user with a mac) but now I can't use it unless I buy a subscription :( I have to stop using now

title: BusyCal review
content: I cannt figure out how to enter events into the Calendar I created. Each time i creeat one a pop-up says I have to put it onto a calendar -- which is what I am tryiung to do

title: Have to pay to use.
content: $4 a month to use or $33 a year. Not worth it just use another free planner/calander like google calander

title: Potential
content: This app is truly great, but they make you buy a seprate app for the iphone ios, why can't I just buy one app and use it across my devices?

title: More Organized!
content: I love how I can add tasks to each day and it shows on the calendar. It helps keep me more organized on what I need to get done. I also love how it seamlessly integrated all of my calendars.

title: Not a free app
content: Although it's apparently possible to cancel within the first two weeks without paying, this app didn't indicate it requires "In-app purchases" in order to use it at all. There's a popup with purchase options that prevents one from doing anything before making some sort of committment. No thanks!

title: luv
content: the best

title: Outstanding Calendar Alternative
content:
My company's SecOps team did a thorough analysis of how BusyCal functions and gave it their seal of approval as an alternative calendar for macOS.  In our environment, we're unable to add personal calendars using Outlook but with BusyCal, I can have my iCloud calendar, other calendar "subscriptions" and my very busy professional calendar in one view - VERY good to have.

I've tried other good calendars like Fantastical, but because they wouldn't pass the security tests my company requires, I'm not able to use them.

BusyCal functionality is excellent and I highly recommend it, not just for every day personal calendaring but if you're concerned about the security of the data, if our company passes it, yours may very well too.

title: Awesome!
content: Was using Fantastical up till now...but BusyCal is so much better!  Only thing Fanstastical has over BusyCal is apple watch app... but otherwise no contest.  BusyCal has a better interface, easier to use.  Love it.

title: Love this and Busy Contacts
content:
This does everything and more. Update improvments often.

Beyond that, the fastest and most competent and personal support I have ever experienced.

Six Stars ******

title: Good Calendar
content: Does exactly what I need it to do.

title: Love the concept - but it's become too buggy
content: I was a huge fan of Airmail when I first subscribed about 2.5 years ago. But lately, it's just become very buggy with everyday type functions. I have an email I cannot delete from my inbox. Emails that I snooze come back to the inbox 2min later. And at times I cannot scroll and have to restart. Wish these would get cleaned up so I go be an advocate again.

title: Best on 2 fronts
content: Busycal works best for me for two reasons. First, I like the available views and the ability to see events and tasks on the calendar at the same time. There are enough options to customize the look/feel without getting lost in a sea of choices. I realize that the look/feel is highly subjective, but it is a good fit for me and the way I work. Second, I _love_ that I can define the CalDAV connection directly in the app so that I can use my own Nextcloud server for calendars/tasks without having to create that account in macOS settings. It means that event/task additions/changes appear on all devices very quickly.

title: Design
content: BusiCal is the best calendar app for Mac as far as I'm concerned. It just need more appearance & layout customization options (colors. fonts, etc)

title: How to display day/week/month
content: In many ways, I love BusyCal.  But now that I am retired (fewer appointments)  work on a laptop almost all the time, I find that the displays for a day or a week display a lot of empty space.  I've tried list view, which eliminates the empty space but doesn't offer a visual organization of my week.  Wish there were a way to get a better display that somehow compromises between the traditional display and the listview, compact but structured.

title: only works on mac
content: in addition to the mac purchase, i have to purchase the mobile version if i want to use on my phone.

title: Deceptive app description
content:
There is no mention in the app description that the only way to use the app is thru a paid subscription, causing people to download and waste their time, as other reviewers have noticed.

Really deceptive. I'll change my rating once that is clearly stated in the app description.

title: Good enough substitute for iCal
content: When your Exchange® sync is broken in Apple's original calendar app, this one acts as a good enough, albeit slightly clunkier, substitute — If (if!) you can tolerate the calamitous circular-week UI “improvement”. That's right, click on today's date at your own risk from the week view; it will make things so that the week appears to start today! This annoyed me enough to bite the bullet, wipe my own Exchange® account and start over from the real app.

title: It's rather...
content: ...meh

title: I would not be ok without this
content: when i tell you i would not survive work/school/personal balance without this app. you can literally make seperate calenders for EVERYTHING. color coded, priority, you name it this freakin app has it. probaby my favorite app i've ever had. i love you.

title: Unfortunate switch to subscription
content: I was an active user of the previous version, but it stopped working. I tried to switch to the new one only to discover that what it is now subscrition service. This is an acceptable approach, but not easy to set up with my employer. So, I was avoiding subscition services when shopping for the new app. Unfortunately, the information presented about the app store missing the most important part, mentioning that you have to pay per month or per year rather tha purchase an app as before. One shoud not wast time and space to download the app to understand that it is a service.

title: Best Calendar app in the world!
content: The annual view for vacations and events far eceeds apple calendar.  For a small compnay to exceed the value of a multi-billion dollar company is remarkable.  Worth 10x the value for busy executives.   Than you BusCal team!

title: I like this more than Fantastical
content: Very simple and clean.

title: Problem taken care of
content: Problem taken care of: The developer contacted me after I left a disatisfied review. They had a fix to my problem on their website. I should have contacted them prior to my review. I hope I have learned my lesson.

title: Pay Gate
content: Makes you go through the entire setup process before informing you that your calendar app is going to cost you $34-$48/year.  I pay for plenty of apps, but delete every one of them that locks your work behind a pay gate you weren't expecting or weren't informed about prior to setup.  Transparancy is an easy practice..

title: Nice Calendar App
content: Very nice calendar that works with all your accounts and devices

title: Brilliant design
content:
I recently had the need to join Google, Microsoft 365 and Apple Calendar into one pretty and refined UI.  BusyCal does the job and looks great doing it.  

Others fail miserably at this.

For those who are whining about having to pay a subscription fee, it's a relatively small price to pay for an app that looks and works great.

title: Amazing features
content: App is full of customizable features that make using it very easy and fun to use.

title: Everything you need in one app
content: Works seemlessly with native apps and syncs wirelessly with the phone app as well.  The one year subscription seems to be worth it so far.  Doing more research to see if the license copy will get updates.

title: Overall I like with One Major Exception
content:
I think this is one of hte best calendars out there. Great interface, and the integrations with various systems is top-notch. I like that I can join a virtual meeting via click on the calendar; I don't have to open the event details. Overall, I like it. 

So, why three stars? Calendar events do not show as busy time unless I explicity check a box. Every other calendar I know of defaults to busy events, and I can't find a way to change this setting. There have been more than a few times where I end up dobule booked becuase of this. 

I really wish they would fix this. It's one of those that will make me pause when it comes time for subscription renewal...

title: Quits program unless you upgrade to the paying version
content:
This is the first review I've ever written, I feel compelled to tell you how bad this app is. 

The developer should tell you that the app is NOT free--to use it, you have to pay an annual or monthly subscription. You only find this out AFTER installing the app.

Specifically, in the AppStore there is no price set, only an "In-App Purchases" note. Once installed, I can't open the app without a nag screen attempting to get me to log in the AppStore to "download" the app already installed. (i.e., to pay for it). If I try to bypass their attempt to access my AppStore login, it goes to a nag screen that tells me to choose a paying plan (monthly or annually). Their only options are to pay or quit.

It was a waste of my time.

title: Love it bbbbbbuuuuuuutttttt.
content: I love how this integrates tasks, weather and it's flexibility with viewing the calendar differnet ways.  I really struggle with buying an application to use on my laptop, then have to buy it again for my iPad and Phone.  The license should cross multiple devices for a single user.  I don't think I would put my name on a recommendation knowing how the buy structure works.  Charge more one time and allow across devices if that's what is needed, but charging multiple times leaves a bad taste in my mouth.

title: Saves Me From Myself
content:
My job involves a lot of deep work. Often I'll be so locked into the task I'm working on that hours will go by without me checking my mail or calendar. I also have multiple screens, and the web-based cal apps and the Apple cal app all only show notifications in the top right corner of the screen. These notifications are remarkably easy for me to miss, and therefore they make it too easy for me to miss the start of an imminent meeting, which I was previously doing often. Not a great look for me.

Busy Cal's pop-up meeting alert panel saves me. I set it to pop up and remain on top of all my other windows until I dismiss it, and to pop up both in advance of and right as a meeting starts, so that I'm prepared for the upcoming meeting too. I never fail to notice it - so finally I'm no longer showing up late for meetings on account of not failing to notice my meeting alerts.

title: Amazing!!
content: This is the best Calendar app for Mac!! Absolutely worth the small subscription fee.

title: Love it
content:
Although I've had both BusyCal and Fantastical installed on Mac and iPhone for what seems ages, recently noticed how much nicer the entire ui of BusyCal looks compared to Fantastical. Honestly, the widgets and list (agenda) views of Fantastical just give me a headache with their extremely contrasting bold fonts. Ugh.

Would really like to see some beautiful hourly / daily forecast widgets for both MacOS and iOS (beautiful with both DARK and LIGHT modes please), that seems like the one thing that's really missing here.

Lastly, "Prefs > Weather > Weather graphics: Large" doesn't seem to be working right; selecting Large appears to be firing the Background selection code path instead. Bug perhaps or I'm missing something?

title: I LOVE
content: Best way to stay organized for college!!!

title: Unclear pricing
content: I don't appreciate not getting pricing info until I have downloaded the app. I support paying for apps and subscription based apps, but don't hid the pricing away from the customer...

title: LOVE!!!!
content: This is by far the best calendar!!!!

title: Love it
content:
Before shifting to BusyCal, I used OpusOne for few years and only had to dump it because there were no versions of the software that support non-mac devices. 

BusyCal provided me all the functinoality and ease of use I experienced with OpusOne in addition to portability. I now use it in my mac book and my android phone, and it syncs flawlessly. I also have to admit that, in my opinion,  BusyCal GUI is much simpler and better than OpusOne.

title: Just does not work over VPM
content: If I'm in the office it works great. If not, it will not reach out over the VPN, (like every single other app I have) and talk to the office server. Otherwise I'd take this into the office in a second and say we need a 50 user license.

title: Started off great...
content:
I used BusyCal and Fanastical side by side for 2 weeks before committing to BusyCal premium. Loved the display, weather integration, colors, agenda etc. Until the delay in synching to my Google calendars became a problem. It is not instantaneous, and the "5-min push" is glitchy. At one point, BusyCal was still showing the original time for an appointment I had already changed in Google and it caused a bit of a panic. I restarted the app and it was still showing the old time. Then I input a few test entries and unfortunately the synching was still a disappointment.

And so the search for the perfect mac calendar app continues!

title: Already paid, have license, but still trying to bill me
content:
I AM ONE OF THE LONGEST BUSYMAC CUSTOMERS, and have used Busycal almost since the very beginning. 
But now, whenever I run the program, a popup window demands that I pay a monthly or annual fee, and will not allow me to access my calendar. My only options are to sign up for a subscription to a program that I have already paid for, or to exit the program.
About a week ago, I sent Busymac a request for help, but have not yet received any acknowledgement of, or reply to, my request. 
My email included my license number, and a screenshot copy of my receipt for payment.
I am completely disgusted with Busymac, AND I DO NOT RECOMMEND THAT YOU PURCHASE THIS PROGRAM.
Martin Weinrich

title: BusyCal
content:
Apple shows BusyCal as a GET program, in other words, free, however, it's NOT.  Apple needs to FIX this.  BusyCal requires a "yeary subscription", which I would expect to see, instead of "GET", and this is misleading. Just be forthright. I had to install BusyCal before I found it doesn't work, TILL you accept their subscription. 
   I don't rent software, so, I'll dump it. If Apple showed in-app purchase required, I would have moved on. BusyCal needs to have Apple fix this. BusyCal should have known how this was listed in the App Store.

title: is it really useful?
content:
I was very excited to try this product. However, I was barely able to scratch the surface with the free trial. As a college student, I really CANNOT afford to pay for this app. It is a shame, I really liked the accesibility more than the standard calendar integrated in my computer. 

If you can afford to pay, please let me know how it works. I fell in love with the app, and then the free trial ended. For the lack of accesibility for those who are of low income (i.e. college students who prefer to use the money on groceries), I give it one star- recognizing that the app itself deserves at least 4!

title: Great app!
content:
Fantastic app. Love it. 

Small recommendations:
1. I wish we could have an option to still see the mini calendar on the left pane (on top of tasks lists)
2. I wish you could have an option to see scheduled calendar events in the task view list under each day

title: almost perfect
content: it could do with a redesign, but I prefer its functionality over all the other calendar apps I tried, including Fantastical. It would be perfect if it looked a little better and had automation in the shortcuts app.

title: Feature Rich, Some Bugs Remain
content: Responsive customer support.

title: I don't do subscriptions.
content: I purchased the license for Busy Cal less than 12 months ago & now I am being asked to select a subscription? I like the calendar, but that was a tacky move. I don't do subscriptions.

title: I like it but....
content: I really really like what this app could be, but I need the To-Do's and Reminders to sync to my phone.  Also, probably operator error but I bought the version for my Macbook and then couldn't figure out how to get the app on my phone.  I finally got it to work sort of, but this is confusing and difficult and honestly not worth the trouble.  Also, do you get the same benefits if you buy the $4.99 IOS version as the $35 Mac version?  If so, I feel a jipped.

title: Best Calendar App Ever!
content: I have cycled through so many calendar and to-do list apps trying to find something that works for me (I'm extremely ADHD but like to stay organized). This is by FAR the best! The functionality is unparalleled, it's easy to use, and it works well on my laptop as well as on mobile. So impressed!

title: almost perfect
content: I really really wish that the color codes I can set up through my tags would carry across to my phone and tablet.  Just being able to glance at something and know instantly by color at what stage of the process it is in just makes work life so much easier.  Otherwise, it is the best calendar I have found for what I need.

title: best calendar app
content: highly worth the $. the hardest part is the initial login/password process, but after that, it works better than any calendar app Ive used. it has made my work/life noticeable easier than apple's native apps

title: Busy Cal to the rescue...
content: I used Busy Cal for some time in order to share and coordinate schedules with the wife.  For I don't know why, we drifted away from all that (probably spoke face-to-face, go figure) and I started using Fantastical.  Works great as well.  But, as many other software developers, a shift to subscription pricing was decided.  And, well, as much as it makes sense at some level, it makes no sense if you consider the user.  I buy a computer that is at least $1000.  Then, I end up having to pay 200/300/400 per month to use wonderful software products.  That is simply crazy.  So, I went looking for a solution.  And then I remembered - BusyCal.  Works wonderfully.  Puts all my calendars in a single place (I work at three institutions) plus my personal calendar and the wife's calendar.  And, we are using it.  Wonderful tool.  Easy to use and set up.  Have it on the Mac, iPad and iPhone.  Good luck everyone!

title: Poor performer for $49.99
content: Not very inuitive.  Trouble opening, connecting to icloud, and formating.  When I enter a calendar event, the words are on top of each other making them illegible.  It is basically a mac calendar with emojis added.  I wish I could get my money back.

title: Busycal Constantly Crashes
content: The app was great until today when began to constantly start crashing as soon as it begins to load. I ininstalled and reinstalled and did numerous restarts and shutdowns to no avail.

title: Excellent Calendar
content: It works flawlessly and is intiutive to use.

title: Ease of Use
content: I've used BusyCal/Mac for many years.  I find it easy to adapt and to any application and use it extensively.   During the school time, especially, I have children and their activities at school, extra curricular activities, mother, husband, my business, et al.  The color coding is my jam.  The calendar was easy to learn and can adapt very well.

title: Good app!
content: Good app!

title: Busy Cal Review
content: The Icon dose not update the current day daily.

title: i paid for bad experience...
content: this app is giving me headec, after i paid it doest work. ....

title: Disruptive Popups
content:
Interrupts workflow with feedback solicitations.

1 star.

Keeps interrupting asking for feedback.

title: iOS version keeps crashing on iphone
content: crashes constantly on iphone

title: To Do Sync Is Slow
content: I have two iOS devices and two MacOS machines. Calendar changes on one of these will show on the others in a reasonable time. To Do changes, however, may take a long time (hours) or not appear at all in the other BusyCal copies.

title: BusyCal is a great option
content: for integrating reminders.  Smooth transition from Apple Calendar.  Has all of the functionality plus integration with reminders app.  Would like to have integration of Notes app and be able to set subtasks within Busycal.  Right now subtasks/todos can only be added directly in the reminders app.  I researched many options, looking for a way to organize across project and with calendar integration.  Very satisifed with this choice and so happy to buy software and avoid an ongoing subscription.

title: Amazing App
content: This is the best app I have found to organize my day and keep track of tasks, highly recommended.

title: Love it
content:
I tried out a number of different calendar apps to find the one that I really love. BusyCal is my favorite aesthetically and because of unique features, such as the ability to add sticky-notes/banners to your day & icons to your events and customize settings to "show weather". 
Your calendar and todo list are both visible 
And ofcourse, it integrates all of my calendars (icloud and google) and syncs across all of my apple devices.

title: Love This App!
content: I rarely write reviews, but BusyCal is an exception. Hands down, the best calendar app for Mac OS and iOS. Definatley worth the money.

title: Best Calendar and To Do solution
content: I've been a Mac user for 35 years, a certified Apple Consultant for most of that time. I've tried most every calendar/scheduling/to-do application available. I always come back to BusyCal and BusyContacts. Gives me every feature I need, stable, looks great.

title: Issues fixed
content: When I first downloaded BusyCal, I was disappointed because one of the features I needed was not working.  The developers reached out to me and offered me a beta version that addressed that issue.  I have now been using BusyCal as my working agenda for a full week and love it! It has allowed me to consolidate all of my calendars and reminders into one and helps me stay organized.  As a small business owner, I truly appreciate this app and the time it has saved me.

title: Not super great
content: First of all, on my iPhone, typing in Korean does not work. And when I try to connect with iCloud, I had a hard time. I hope you guys can fix atleast the Korean problem please. Thanks.

title: Ugh...
content: A pretty good app that I've used for years, but now after every update it wants me to review it, which gets annoying when using/updating on multiple machines.   It was bad enough when they rolled out updates every other day last year, but this is another round of annoyance that's again tempting me to look for alternatives.   ENOUGH!

title: Best Calendar App for multiple accounts
content:
Have used this app for many years and have not been dissapointed. I have several calendars that I need to sync up. Persoan, Work and multiple customers. BusyCal keeps them all in line.
Thanks keep up the good Code.

title: Why pester me with review requests?
content: The software is good and there is much to like. But I hate when software pesters me for review requests!

title: Efficient and Well Written!
content: This is one of the few apps that really pays for itself.  It is so good that Apple should purchase rights to this program so that they can learn how a well designed contact app should function.  It syncs extremely fast with iCal and Messages.  This is definitely a must have.  The only thing it is missing is a companion computer app.  But, you really don't need it.

title: need more beautiful graphics....
content:
I particularly like that the calendar can be set for timezones when I travel.

BUT  I would like sexier graphics like google

title: A fun but useful calendar
content: I really like being able to place photos and other graphics into my events providing a quick visual reminder. Also, all the events are listed in the monthly view - I need only to scroll and don't need to go into each of the "2 other events" to find out what they are. Having the to-do list right next to the calendar is hlepful as well.

title: Won't stop asking me for a review
content:
constantly with the popups asking for a review. BusyCal used to be a good app.

ETA: No, it asks me for a review EVERY TIME I launch it. I quit and re-launched it again just now, and it asked for a review AGAIN even though I've already left a review. There's something wrong with the programming.

ETA 2: Quit and re-launched again and it asked for a review AGAIN.

title: Works well with multiple calendars
content:
I had been struggling with keeping multiple calendars synced (Outlook, Google, Mac) and BusyCal manages them all.

I alos like being able to have multiple timezones displayed - I work with employees in other timezones, and ths really helps me quickly schedule meetings.

title: Love BusyCal
content:
It is far superior to Apple Candle!   Love the color coding options, the coordinating todo options, the flexibility of the users choice to show this or that list and not show another.  Very well planned, maintained, and a long time standard for me on my macbook pro!   I've tried others..... none compare.

Only addition I'd like to see is a user "NOTES" page along side of (or 1 click away ) where a user can write long details of the day, events, add pictures or files attached to the date but on a separate full page per day.  It would function somewhat like where they allow you to put "notes" at the end of each event, journal, banner, todo, or timed todo, but would provide you a dedicated space for each day (although you wouldn't have to write on each day .....so just a daily template available you could click to bring up) where you put other things happening that won't fit on the little squares of monthly calendar boxes.   BTW  I know you can type on the daily page, but it' s not geared to journaling or recording events and the details or adding pictures, files  or memories  for the day. 

Overall, I'd give them 10 stars for the functionality, reliability, fast email customer service requests, color coding, syncing !!!  PERFECT SYNCING!! and the daily view which I find very helpful...like a timeline.  Keep up the good work guys!

title: It has features that I love, but it's pretty buggy
content: Like right now, an incorrect date is showing in my task bar.

title: Love it
content: Easy to use and much for feature filled than the default Calendar app

title: just a few drawbacks, but important ones...
content:
dock icon date gets stuck on past dates.
doesnt seem to get the auto suggested events via iCal by scanning emails, etc...

title: Nice layout and user friendly
content: Thus far, has worked reliably. Improvements in the past couple of years have made it even more useful.

title: This is the calendar for the visually inclined
content:
Oh, goodness, so much happiness to find a calendar that makes for a very visual experience. Want to see scroilling weeks instead of one month at a time? No problem! Want a handy pop up to tell you what month you're in while scrolling? Also, no problem!  So many thoughtful little gems make this a great experience.

It also is made for those who have to juggle calendars from several sources, including google. This app understands that if a calendar is *shared* with you, you will probably want to *see* it as part of your list. This is the only app I could find that accomplished that without jumping through hoops or trudging through pages of settings. 

Brava!

title: So much better than Apple's Calendar
content:
I've been using the BusyMac suite of BusyCal and BusyContacts for years now and feel they deserve an upate.  These programs work seamlessly with iCloud and offer features that simply don't exist in Apple's native apps.  (I'm not sure why BusyContacts isn't coming up on the App Store but I highly recommend it as a basic CRM app.)

In addition to these being well-developed apps, I want to mention the excellent tech support offered by the developer.  I usually get a response by email within 24 hours and they have never failed to figure out the problem and provide a solution on the rare occasions when I've had an issue. 5 stars all the way!

title: overpriced and underwhelming
content: really expected more of this $50 app ... It doesn't have as many features as the free Cal program that comes free with Mac software.  It does not automatically go to today's date when opened.  Inserting new entries is degraded (i.e. from Cal or Fantastical) - I like the blue icon - other than that blue icon, this program is completely disapointing compared with its peers.

title: I Really Like this App
content: I have tried lots of task management apps over the years. Since I prefer to keep my calendar and tasks together, Informant 5 and Fantastical have been my favorites over other popular apps like Omni Focus and Things. I liked Informant 5 because it was a pretty robust task manager; I like Fantastical because I could just drag items from the todo list on to relevant days of the week. BusyCal offers me the best of both of those worlds. Like Fantastical, BusyCal uses the native Apple Reminders which can then be dragged to, and moved around on the calendar. But much to my delight, BusyCal ADDS to Apple Reminders with tags, filters, and more that turn Apple Reminders into a pretty powerful task management system for me. I also like that I can add graphics, stickies, and journal entries to different days. This past year, I also began using the new Notion.so app for notes, files etc, which makes it pretty slick to simply add a URL to access all of the rest of my work on a project. Conversely, I can highlight something in Notion.so and use the Apple share sheet to add it to Apple Reminders and get a new todo item from my notes into BusyCal. So, I honestly think BusyCal is the best solution I've found, yet, for managing tasks and calendar together. Thank you!

title: Good
content: I with it truncated appointment and meeting titles in the Monthly view.  Is there any integration with a notes app?

title: Nice design, too Apple "Centric" Reminders
content: We use G suite and thus Google calendar. We use Todoist for Reminders which are a critical thing to have integrated with your events so at least you can access them. I went to add ToDois to the "reminders" account field and it will not let me add anything other than Apple Reminders. Very disappointed--other than that great app.

title: App Specific for OS
content: Every time I update the OS version on my Mac, Mac Book, Macbook air, the BusyContacts, BusyCal & other Busy App stop synchronizing until I re-set the App Specific passwords. It's actually a pain in the rear each time. I've stopped using these apps and gone back to the original Calendar and Contacts.

title: Great calendar!
content: So much more intuitive to use than other calendars I’ve tried!  Areas for improvement:  1.  Better iOS functionality (way better interface on laptop than on ipad/iphone)  2. When searching events, they appear in black font instead of the user’s preferred color, making events harder to quickly search/scan)

title: Organized!
content: Nicely done BusyCal.  Straight to the point!  Easy setup.  I’m very pleased with this calendar App!

title: It just works.
content:
I like BusyCal because I don't feel like the application gets in the way of the job I need it to do.

There are three things it does well that are particularly important to me. 

BusyCal loads very quickly and doesn't use a ton of resources. Some calendar apps I've tried took far too long to load. This meant I couldn't add or change something unless the program was already running. Having to wait took me out of the moment and broke my flow. BusyCal doesn't have this problem.

My calendar is always available. BusyCal puts an icon in the menu bar. Other programs have done this, but the program had to be running in the background for the menu bar icon to be available. The BusyCal menubar icon is ALWAYS there whether or not the program is running, so I can see my schedule whenever I want and can enter things on the fly. 

Finally, I really like BusyCal's monthly view. It lets me see up to 12 weeks at a time and can scroll indefinitely.

Using BusyCal, I feel like I'm interacting with my schedule, not my calendar program.

title: More desktop notifications i don’t need
content: Not helpful. How can I get a refund?

title: Great functionality, slow performance
content:
For a calendar app BusyCal seems to offer a lot of interesting features and visual presentation also works for me pretty well.
Unfortunetely adding my main calendar (which has a lot of events) makes the UI slugish. Day view is crap to use (about 3-5 frames per second), but switching to week view it goes bellow 2fps. The same calendar in Outlook renders smoothly (60fps).
I have a lot of repeated meetings, I have found online that for more then 200 reps the devs recommend splitting them up - none of mine are above 200 though (they are either infinite or about 20 reps). So that doesn't seem to be an issue. Anyway, that performance makes this software unusable for me. For 50$ that performance is not acceptable.

title: Good calendar, still has a little work to do
content:
I have been using busycal as a replacement for outlook. I like the fact that busycal places my to do list where I can see it alongside my calendar. Busycal works well with my exchange calendar as well as family google calendar. 
What needs work: Inviting multiple people to an event does not work well. Once the invite event has been placed, it is difficult to modify it. 
Also, as an aesthetic preference, it would be nice if multiple day events were highlighted according to their tag color. That way I can easily see the extent of the event. 

I like the calendar much better than other App store options.

title: Best Mac Calendar
content: I have hundreds of calendars, organized into groups, each group shared with different people. In Apple’s app they show up as an unusable list of hundreds of calendars. In Busycal I can put them into groups, collapse each group and show or hide whole groups at a time. This is essential if you have a large number of calendars. I have several different iCloud and Google accounts all syncing easily with BusyCal. The menubar dropdown is well thought out. Great calendar!

title: Favorite calendar app for Mac
content:
I really like BusyCal! Especially the drop-down interface for the menu bar. It’s very handy to see a concise graphical representation of the month and the upcoming events and meetings.

My favorite part is the graphical design of the app. It looks really nice. I was for a time torn between BusyCal and Fantasitcal, however I am glad I decided to stay with BusyCal. I do use Fantastical on my iOS devices, however. I do like those apps. They just seem to quickly grow old since I feel like I am looking at the same thing every day whereas with BusiCal - it seems to be changing and changeable. Like life.

I also broke down and bought BusyContacts. Although I do like that app, I would never be happy until I had both apps paired together. Maybe you will like it as much as I do?

title: Do not purchase
content: This is no better than iCal and you pay 50.00 for nothing.  Then no one responds to your emails.

title: I would hate to use anything else
content: I have been using BusyCal for several years now, and I love it. I love having my events and to dos in the same calendar. I love the ease with which everything syncs between my devices (MacBook, iMac, iPhone, and iPad).

title: can’t download after update
content: stopped working after update - removed the app and I can’t download again (w/o paying).

title: Works for iCloud, Gmail and Exchange PERFECTLY
content: I just want my apps to work and services to work together. This works beautifully. I am a heavy user of iCloud, MS Exchange and Gmail but Outlook for Mac doesn’t play well with iCloud and iCal doesn’t ever seem to do a good job of keeping my MS Exchange invites in sync. I was close to giving up but someone suggested BusyCal… within 5 mins I had it downloaded, configured and working. It JUST WORKS! Love it. Finally! Something that works like it should.

title: Would have given it 5 Stars if….
content: I would like to see graphic icons attached to the Event Calendars.  Birthday calendars would automatically have your chosen icon appear when you add a birthday.  As it is, you have to add your icon every time you add a birthday, or event.   I use icons as a quick way to scan my day or week.  An envelope at the top of my day tells me a bill is due, a cupcake with candle reminds me of a birthday, etc.  These all have to be added individually, it would be nice to just add them to Event Calendar preference pane so they would  appear automatically.

title: Great and extremely professional
content: BusyCal is extremely professional and addresses all my needs, particular in conjunction with BusyContacts.

title: Productivity booster
content: I like that this calendar doesn’t seem to get in the way, yet it also has all the power features I want. I had been using Fantastical. I liked it, but it din’t flow as smoothly as BusyCal for me. It was not nearly as plain vanilla to work with as BusyCal. And although the iOS version of BusyCal isn’t terribly pretty, it gets the job done. The BusyCal approach is just plain simple. And uncomplicated is what I need when it comes to throwing appointments at my devices. I kind of think the prettier UI of Fantastical comes at a price - the shiny wrapper tends to get in the way of functionality just a little bit. If you are looking for a truly simple and easy to manage calendar/todo package for your Mac and iOS devices, with enough horsepower to manage a busy life, give BusyCall a try; it should serve you well. It’s certainly checked all the boxes for me.

title: Two-factor authentication
content:
I like the BusyCal 3 app, but Apple now required two-factor authentication. I set up an app-specific password in BusyCal, but it never seems to work. And it is DRIVING ME CRAZY! I keep getting a prompt to enter the app-specify password. I put in the one I registered, and it doesn’t work. I keep getting the same prompt. So I enter my Apple ID (since the prompt shows my Apple username), but that doesn’t work! This constant pop-up prompt has rendered my use of the application impossible. I ran into this previously, but was able to disable two-factor authentication. But now Apple seems to require it and I can’t get this password-thing to work. So far, no problem with BusyContat, but maybe it’s a matter of time…….?

Follow-up: I tried the BusyCal website and found directions for the set-up of the two-factor authentication. These directions were helpful; but the process is not intuitive.

title: Best calendar program, period.
content: I have a lot to keep track of and BusyCal is the easiest, most flexible, and full featured program out there. I looked at other calendars and they just didn’t offer the depth of functions that BusyCal does.  Great program!

title: Paper-less Planning
content: I decided recently to discontinue my use of a paper planner, and my biggest concern for a digital calendar/task manager was finding an app that had to-do lists and calendar events in the same view.  I found this app worked really well for my planning needs due to its combined calendar/list nature and ability to be used across all of my devices (Mac, iPad, iPhone). I have found it much more efficient than a paper planner.  It has many customizable features that I am happy with and am still discovering as I use it; including basic integration with other apps like google cal, Asana, and Evernote.  If I could add a feature it would be to be able to manually organize to dos on a certain day in the “Day” (not “to do list”) view since they automatically put them in alphabetical order.

title: Cleaner look
content: Love cleaner look of the calendar and brightness of the colors!!

title: Great calendar app
content: I have tried Apple’s calendar app as well as fantastical. If you are working with a lot of shared calendars via office365 this is probably the best one to you use. It is easier on the eyes than Fantastical. The bar widget is quick and easy to use. Excellent app.

title: Interface not as good
content:
BusyCal 3 functions exactly like BusyCal 2 so if you liked what that does you will like this one. BusyCal 3 offers compliance with upcoming requirements of Google calendars in particular so it is necessary to switch to this from BusyCal 2 if you’d like top view a Google calendar with the application.

The problem my business has with BusyCal 3 is that the interface has been ‘updated’ to a more ‘flat’ design I would guess to more closely match an Apple or Google calendar web view. This is not a good thing as it’s harder on the eyes to figure out what’s going on if you have a complex situation with multiple calendars, such as a business with a dozen users. The banners across the top can be switched back to ‘classic’ view giving the familiar one pixel border that helps distinguish one banner event from the other. This classic option is not available for calendar events themselves, however, and that is really too bad. PLEASE PROVIDE CLASSIC VIEW FOR CALENDAR EVENTS for increased functionality. Our business switched to BusyCal 2 because of the UI changes in Apple’s Calendar, and now BusyCal 3 is mimicking that flawed product.

The other interface problem is that the highlight color for the current time and the current day has switched from a sedate blue to a distractingly garish vivid purple color (as seen in the screenshot above), irregardless of your selection for highlight color made in System Preferences > Appearance > Highlight color. No good; too distracting, too much visual impact. Dial it back. What were you thinking? Why not add functionality so that users can pick their own color, or provide a more neutral color. Also, the dock icon of BusyCal2 showed a neutral grid when the application was not active, and the day’s actual date when it was active. This functionality is lost on this version as it always shows ‘May 27’ when the application is not active, losing the quick visual cue to let you know that the app is not running. Bad interface design decisions all the way around here.

In regards to the developer response: I appreciate that you have taken the time to share some words, but they do not actually address my issues. Your response re: the garish purple highlight is flatly wrong, and your other suggestions do not address the fundamental critique of your downgrades to the interface (although they claim to be solutions). Therefore I am lowering your rating from 2 stars to 1 because I cannot abide a response that attempts to disingenuously blunt the force of my review with obfuscation.

title: ALL IN ONE!
content: Its an amazing app and it meets all of my needs. I love the fact that I can handle siri reminders and also sync with google calendar. Hands down the best one out there, way better than fantastical.

title: BusyCal came recommended, didn’t disappoint!
content:
This is a great substitute for Apple Calendar and so similar, there’s no learning curve.  It’s almost like a new front-end to the same Apple program.  And it’s a much better value than Fantastical.  It doesn’t crash nor does it slow down my mid-2010 iMac.  I would rate it 5-starts if it had one additional feature.

Unlike Apple Calendar’s dynamic app icon, the BusyCal app icon has a static date of May 27th WHEN it’s not running.  But BusyCal uses a dynamic icon AFTER you start the program.  I first started using BusyCal at the end of the month and didn’t realize this suptle difference at first.  It REALLY screwed me up when I was a day off so this is an issue with me.  Admittedly it does show the name of the month in a super-small font but for years I’ve grown accustomed to only having to quickly glance down at my dock to get the date.  And I limit the number of open programs running in the background.

It’s a minor issue that cost a star but I would still recommend the program.

title: Not ready for prime time
content: You are considering updating from 2.X - do not. This version has many bugs and poorly designed UI changes. It is not as well thought out as the older version. Who knows is the upgrades will fix the issues or not. I wish I had not spent the money and just kept using the older version. Nothing gained.
